What most struck me, was the resignation of villagers. They're used to struggle for medical care, whether for covid or any other disease. As one villager said: ‚ÄòIf you get better, you get better. If you don't get better, you die and it's over.‚Äô 
Article: https://t.co/ljhVmrJwRq

It's difficult to assess impact of lack of medical care, without credible numbers on infections, serious illnesses, deaths. Pple were vague (it's taboo), but described increased demand for cremation, graves, funeral ceremonies. One source estimated 3-4x more deaths than normal.

Seriously ill villagers need to go to county hospital for good care (1 hour drive away), but face many obstacles. Most villagers don't have a car. Many can't afford expense (partially reimbursed). County hospitals were also full during covid wave, many used connections to get in.

A doctor in town hospital confirmed lack of beds and medication during covid wave. Almost all medical staff was infected but admirably kept working. But hospital has mostly doctors with low education (and low salary) and cannot treat serious patients. There's no IC department.

The 72y old doctor was released from hospital day before and back in his (poorly equipped) clinic, even though he wasn't fully recovered. 'If I'm not here, there's no one', he said. He couldn't find a replacement, and complained of low salary (<20.000RMB/y) and heavy workload.

I went to Shitouzui, a town (with a hospital) with 41 villages (with 26 clinics). One clinic had a 76y old village doctor, another a 72y old one. When covid hit, they had no protection, no tests, no medication. They both got infected and were hospitalized. Their clinics closed.
